efq7zok.Author: BashCo
efq7zok.Text:
The Electrum Phishing attacks are still ongoing. Electrum users should update their software and verify the signature before installing. Do not update Electrum from any URLs found in in-app notifications. Here are two official sources.

* https://electrum.org/#download
* https://github.com/spesmilo/electrum

efpyaj6.Author: BitcoinAlways
efpyaj6.Text:
**Bitcoin Price Charts Offer Glimmer of Hope to Struggling Bulls**

[**https://www.coindesk.com/bitcoin-price-charts-offer-glimmer-of-hope-to-struggling-bulls**](https://www.coindesk.com/bitcoin-price-charts-offer-glimmer-of-hope-to-struggling-bulls)

 

### View

* Bitcoin has charted a falling wedge pattern on the daily chart. A break above $3,450 would confirm a wedge breakout and expose key resistance lined up at $3,658 (the high of the gravestone doji candle created on Jan. 26). A violation there would expose the psychological resistance of $4,000.
* The prospects of a falling wedge breakout would weaken if the cryptocurrency suffers a channel breakdown on the 4-hour chart.

The slow drip bitcoin (BTC) price sell-off seen over the last six weeks has produced a bullish pattern on the daily chart.

The leading cryptocurrency by market value is currently down more than 20 percent from highs above $4,200 seen on Dec. 24. The pullback may have reinforced the primary bearish trend, as represented by the long-term moving average studies.

Still, all is not lost for the bulls, as the lower highs and lower lows created over the last six weeks have converged, creating a downward sloping cone or a falling wedge on the daily chart.

The falling wedge is a bullish reversal pattern, that is, the price will often break above the upper edge of the pattern and rally. A breakout, if confirmed, could open the doors for a strong corrective move.

As of writing, BTC is trading at $3,400 on Bitstamp, representing a 0.66 percent drop on the day. The falling wedge resistance is seen at $3,450.

​

**More on link above.**

efqmglm.Author: cryptogrip
efqmglm.Text:
Transaction fees have leveled off in a very affordable range. These days, the total fees paid to miners is approximately $76,000 per day for about 300,000 different transactions. That makes the average fee is only 25 cents per transaction. 

There's also the overhead for much further improvement on top of this again. Honestly, I'd say this will continue to improve along with all the other bitcoin developments for years to come. Remember we are in extremely early days. The lightning network is a second layer over the bitcoin network, and lets people transfer Bitcoin instantly and without any fees. It creates payment channels between the users.  Imagine the endless possibilities of a payment system that can reach anyone instantly with no overhead. What has happened over recent years with audio and video streaming will likely happen to money. Streaming money! 

Remember, one of the main advantages that bitcoin brings us is to use money as routable digital content. The future of money is being built, and one only needs to look around at the past and the present to realistically envision the future of bitcoin.

efqlph3.Author: CommunistAndy
efqlph3.Text: No, btc is not ready for another bull run at all. If one happens in the next year or so btc will most likely be dethroned...

efrf9xr.Author: Crude_Answer
efrf9xr.Text:
Yes. Just look and think about your premise. The fact that there is a large number of "lost forever" bitcoins is in itself a problem. How do you think it came to be?

No one thinks it will happen to them, until it does.

The security of Bitcoin is both a strength and weakness. 

Ex: What happens if your fiat gets robbed from a bank account in the US? It gets insured by the FDIC up to 250k. Your credit info got stolen? Fraud protection. 

What happens if your crypto gets hacked from an exchange or your wallet? Your crypto is gone forever and everyone tells you to be more tech savvy.

efqhgfi.Author: cryptogrip
efqhgfi.Text: It's like most technology - Once the development breaches the threshold where its use provides easy to identify advantages to the average person, the demand will increase, and the price along with it. The last few bubbles were speculation driven, and that may even drive the next one. But like all tech we will get there, and for now, accumulation in small regular buys still seems to be the best strategy regardless of all this looking for signs and signals stuff. Because once this thing kicks in, I mean really kicks in, there will be no more buying bitcoin sub 20k. Let the builders build, buy when you can, and ignore the trolls and their ignorance.

efr0smg.Author: 1561KWP
efr0smg.Text: Maybe some people lost money?  Maybe they can sell their btc to pay off the winners. (or pay the winner with btc).

efr9tff.Author: cryptogrip
efr9tff.Text:
Nobody can possibly have those answers. The price doesn't follow an exact pattern. It reflects the public demand. Any development could occur at any time that changes things. All we know is that bitcoin has been growing steadily for a decade in terms of the technology and how it is being implemented via improvements, exchanges, apps, platforms, regulations, etc.

Just remember, there was a time when skeptics laughed and mocked the possibility of a $100 bitcoin. Since its inception it has been overcoming all odds.

efsl1gn.Author: cubalibre101
efsl1gn.Text:
Why less appealing? The fact that lost coins are gone forever just shows how incredibly secure the network is. No hacker, no government, no agency, no company - no one ever can move your funds. As long as you keep your private keys: Your keys, your funds. But also: No keys, no funds.  For the first time in the digital age, something digital is actually scarce. Digital scarcity is one of bitcoins key features.

efrxbj6.Author: DemonPuke
efrxbj6.Text: Nobody is telling you to trust an online exchange, there has been an insane amount of work put in by the community to educate people on the saying "not your keys not your coins" at this point ten years down the road if people are still moronically leaving their bitcoins on an online exchange instead of securing it in their own wallet they control is simply ignorant and we as a community still need to preach "not your keys not your coins" this happening is yet another reason to keep your bitcoins out of other people's hands and in your own, do not confuse an exchange fucking up a Bitcoin Network problem because it is totally different.
